From: "Pigneri, Rocco" <rpigneri@...>
Subject: RE: [junit] Re: Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or IsCollection.isEmpty()
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=383279107
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

David,

 

>How about
>
>assertReturned(0).from(list).size();
>
>A little yoda-esque, but much shorter. And I've already implemented
>that one once.

Interesting.  I really like this notation.  This seems like a natural
fit for primitives and for objects would only require that our users
implement useful equals(...) functions.  The one place where I could see
this performing badly is when the user wants to output a list of objects
since most lists don't implement element equality.

 

Speaking of lists, how can this notation be expanded for use in testing
lists?  While Hamcrest's current support for lists seems somewhat
spotty-I haven't used it too, too much so I could be wrong-it has the
capability to be expanded to provide robust support for lists.  Using a
Hamcrest-like notation, NUnit allows you to say things like this:

 

Assert.That( iarray, Has.No.Null );

Assert.That( iarray, Is.Unique );

Assert.That( iarray, Has.All.GreaterThan(0) );

Assert.That( iarray, Has.Some.GreaterThan(2) );

 

You'll notice that in this case, we are mixing matchers (Is/Has,
All/No/Some, GreaterThan, and Null) in order to test this list using
matchers that are not named after functions on the list under test.
You'll also notice that the mixing of the matchers allows us to produce
rather powerful combinations that are not necessarily foreseen by the
JUnit developers.  Will this new notation support such extensions as
well?

 

Thank you,

 

Rocco 

 

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
David Saff
Sent: Wednesday, May 20, 2009 10:15 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or
IsCollection.isEmpty()

 






On Tue, May 19, 2009 at 6:50 PM, Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@...
<mailto:nat.pryce%40gmail.com> > wrote:
> 2009/5/19 David Saff <david@... <mailto:david%40saff.net> >:
>> I see the single-arg assertThat as sugar on top of exactly that
>> implementation, so the following would be equivalent:
>>
>> assertThat(list).isEmpty();
>> assertThat(list, theAforementioned(List.class).isEmpty());
>>
>> Yes, some serious work needs to be done on naming on the second line,
>> but hopefully the idea is clear.
>
> Definitely. I was thinking of something along those lines.
>
> As for objects that return a non-boolean result, there could (maybe,
> not sure how) be a three-parameter version like:
>
> assertThat(list,
theAforementioned(List.class).size()).is(equalTo(0)));

How about

assertReturned(0).from(list).size();

A little yoda-esque, but much shorter. And I've already implemented
that one once.

David Saff





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
subject: RE: [junit] Re: Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or IsCollection.isEmpty()
